sp.p: If I do knock, he won't open itHe won't open it: A note of interrogation seems out of place after "recludet.".

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Then break the pannelBreak the pannel: "Panem frangite" Literally, "break the bread," meaning the "pannel." He plays upon the resemblance of the verb "pulto," "to knock," and "puls," "pottage.".

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: If the Procurer comes out, do you think I ought to enquire of the fellow whether my slave has come to him or not?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: With two hundred golden Philippean pieces?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Then the Procurer will be going astray at once.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: About what matter?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Do you ask? Because a less sum will be named by one hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: You judge rightly.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: He'll think that some other person is being looked after.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: No doubt.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: He'll be denying it at once.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: On his oath even.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: The fellow will involve himself in the guilt of theft----

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Beyond a doubt, it certainly is so.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Of however much it is that shall have been brough to him.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Jupiter confound youJupiter confound you: For their repeated and tiresome answers of "quippini?" "why not?"!

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Why not your own self?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: going towards the door of LYCUS. I'll go and knock at this door.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Even so. Why not?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: It's time to be quiet, for the door makes a noise. I see the Procurer Lycus coming out of doors; come this way, pray!

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: Why not? But, if you please, cover up our heads, that the Procurer mayn't know us, who have been his decoyersHis decoyers: "Illices." "Illex" was a bird-call, quail-pipe, or decoy used by fowlers for catching birds. into so great a calamity. He throws the lappets of their garments over their heads.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: to himself. Let all soothsayers go hang themselves now at once. Why should I believe them in future, as to what they say? For they, just now at the sacrifice, told me that evil and the greatest disaster was portended to me. I have since then amplified my fortune with profit.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: accosting him. Save you, Procurer.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: May the Gods bless you, Agorastocles.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You now salute me more kindly than hitherto.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: A calm has come, as though to a ship at sea. Just as the wind is, to that quarter is the sail shifted.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: May those ladies be well in your house, to whom I wish it, but to yourself I do not wish it.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: They are well, as you desire; not for you, though.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Send your Adelphasium to my house, to-day, please, upon this celebrated and famous festival, the Aphrodisia.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Have you been breakfasting on a hot breakfast today? Tell me.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Because now you are only cooling your mouthCooling your mouth: Because in opening the mouth, the air tends to cool it, when you ask me.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Attend to this, Procurer, will you; I've heard that my slave is at your house.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: At my house? You'll find that has never been the fact.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You lie; for he has come to your house, and carried off some gold there. Word has been brought me to that effect, by persons I fully believe. Pointing to the ASSISTANTS.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: You are an artful fellow: you've come to entrap me with your witnesses. There's no one of your people in my house, nor anything of yours.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: turning round to the ASSISTANTS. Remember that, assistants.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: We will remember it.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: laughing. Ha, ha, ha! I now understand how it is, I've this instant seen through it. These persons, who a short time since introduced that Spartan stranger to me, their brain is now fired at it, because I'm going to make a gain of these three hundred Philippean pieces; now, because they knew that this person was an enemy of mine, they have set him on to say that his slave, together with his gold, is in my house. It's a planned contrivance for them to deprive me of it, and to divide it among themselves. They are wanting to get away the lamb from the wolfLamb from the wolf: In allusion to his own name.. They are wasting their pains.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What, do you deny that either the gold or my slave is at your house?

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I do deny it; and, if it's of any use, I make myself hoarse with denying it.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: You are undone, Procurer; for that person whom we told you was a Spartan, is his bailiff; who brought you just now the three hundred Philippean pieces; and that same gold, too, is in his purse.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: shaking his fist at them. Woe unto you!

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: That, indeed, is close at hand for yourself.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Come, you hang-dog, give up the purse this instant. You are clearly a thief; caught by me in the fact. (To the ADVOCATI.) By my troth, I do beg of you, lend me your aid, so as to see me bring my slave out of his house. He goes into the PROCURER'S house.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I' faith, I'm now undone for certain, beyond a doubt! This has been done on purpose that a snare might be laid for me. But why do I hesitate to betake me hence to utter perdition, before I'm dragged off to the Prætor by the throat? Alas! what soothsayers I've been having for my diviners, who, if they promise anything that's fair, it comes to pass but slowly; that which they promise as unfortunate, comes directly. Now I'll be off: I'll consult my friends in what way--they deem it best in especial for me to hang myself. (Exit.)

div2.stage: Enter AGORASTOCLES, from the house of LYCUS, driving out COLLYBISCUS.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Be off you, get out you, that the witnesses may see you coining out from here. Isn't this my servant? To the ASSISTANTS.

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: I' faith, I really am, Agorastocles.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: How now, villanous Procurer?

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: He, with whom you have the dispute, has made off.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I hope he's gone hence to utter perdition.

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: It's proper that we should wish the same.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: To-morrow I'll bring my action against the fellow.

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: Anything further with me----?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You may go; put on your own dress.

sp.speaker: COLLYBISCUS
sp.p: It wasn't for nothing that I turned soldier. I made a little booty in-doors. While the household of the Procurer was asleep, I got myself well filled with the entrails. I'll be off from here in-doors.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: to the ASSISTANTS. 'Twas kindly done by you. Assistants, you have lent me your good services. To-morrow morning I beg you'll meet me at the court of justice. To COLLYBISCUS. Do you follow me in-doors. To the ASSISTANTS. To you, farewell!

sp.speaker: ADVOCATI
sp.p: And you, farewell! (AGORASTOCLES goes into his house, followed by COLLYBISCUS.) This fellow wants a thing that's notoriously unfair; he thinks that we are to serve him at our own expense. But such are all these rich people of ours: if you do anything of service, their thanks are lighter than a feather; if there's any offence, they show vengeance like lead. Let's now go to our houses, if you like, forthwith, since we've effected that for which we lent our services, to ruin this corrupter of our fellow-citizens. (Exeunt.)

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I'm awaiting in what way my plot is to proceed. I'm bent upon ruining this Procurer, since he torments my afflicted master; but he in his turn beats me, and strikes me with his fist and heels. It's a misery to be in the service of one who is in love, especially one who is debarred from the object which he woos. Heyday! I see Syncerastus, the Procurer's servant, betaking himself from the Temple. I'll listen to what he has to say. He stands aside.

div2.stage: Enter SYNCERASTUS, with some cooking utensils, from the Temple of Venus.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: to himself It's quite clear that Gods and men neglect the benefit of him who has a master like a person of such character as I have for a master. There's not another person anywhere in the world more perjured or more wicked than is my master, nor one so filthy or so defiled with dirt. So may the Gods bless me, I'd rather pass my life either in the stone quarries or at the mill, with my sides hampered with heavy irons, than pass this servitude with a Procurer. What a race this is! What corruptors of men they are! Ye Gods, by our hopes in you, every kind of men you may see there, just as though you had come to Acheron --horse and foot, a freed-man, a thief, or a runaway, if you choose, one whipped, chained, or condemned to slavery. He who has got money to pay, whatever sort of person he is--all kinds are taken in; throughout all the house, in consequence, are darkened spots and hiding-places: drinking and eating are going on, just as though in a cookshop, and in no less degree. There may you see epistles written in letters inscribed on potteryInscribed on pottery: He alludes to the marks denoting the age of wine, which were placed upon the "amphoræ" or "cadi," the earthenware casks. These were stopped tight with wood or cork, made impervious to the atmosphere with pitch (as here mentioned), or with clay, or a composition of gypsum. On the outside the title of the wine was either painted, or inscribed in earthenware letters, which are here alluded to. The date of the vintage was denoted by the names of the Consuls then in office. When the vessels were of glass, small tickets, called "pittacia," were suspended from them stating to a similar effect., and sealed with pitch: the names are upon them in letters a cubit long; such a perfect levy on vintnersLevy of vintners: He calls the worthless characters who are skulking in his master's house "vinarii," " vintners," from their love for wine, of which the Procurer seems to be in possession of a choice stock. have we got at our house.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: apart. Upon my faith, it is quite wonderful, if his master doesn't make him his heir; for really, the way he soliloquizes, he's making a speech over him as though dead and gone. I'd both like to accost the fellow, and yet I listen to him with extreme delight.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: to himself. When I see these things going on, I'm vexed that slaves, purchased at the heaviest price, should at our house be robbed of the savingsRobbed of the savings: "Expeculiatas." He alludes to those slaves who, having run away from their masters, are lurking in the Procurer's house, where they spend all their savings (peculium), which, by rights, should go to their masters towards the purchase of their freedom. which ought to go to their masters. But at last nothing is left visible: "badly gotten, badly gone."

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: apart. This man goes on talking quite as though he himself were an honest fellow, when, upon my faith, he himself is able to make worthlessness more worthless.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: to himself. Now I'm taking home these vessels from the Temple of Venus, where with his sacrifice my master has not been able to propitiate Venus on her festive day.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: apart. Charming Venus!

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: to himself. But our Courtesans, with their first ictims, appeased Venus in an instant.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: O charming Venus, once again!

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: moving. Now I'll go home.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: coming forward. Hallo! Syncerastus!

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: looking around. Who's calling Syncerastus?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Your friend.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: You don't act like a friend, in causing me delay when I've got a burden.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: But in return for this matter I'll lend you my aid, when you please, and when you give me your commands. Consider the agreement signed.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: If so it is to be, I'll give you my services in this----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Why that, when I'm to have a beating, you yourself may substitute your hide.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Get along with you.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I don't understand what sort of person you are.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I'm good for nothing.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Be so to yourself, then.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I want you.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: But my burden is pressing me.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Then, do you set it down, and turn your face to me.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I'll do so, although I have no leisure. Putts down his load.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Save you, Syncerastus.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: O Milphio, may all the Gods and Goddesses favour----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What person, pray?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Neither you, nor me, Milphio, nor my own master, in fact.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Whom are they to favour, then?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Any one else they please; for not one of us is de serving of it.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: You speak wittily.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: It befits me to do so.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What are you doing?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I'm doing that which, clearly, adulterers don't generally do.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Bringing all off in safetyAll of in safety: There is an indecent allusion in this passage which is modified in the translation..

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: May the Gods confound you and your master!

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: May they not confound me. I could make them ruin him, if I chose--ruin my master, did I not fear for myself, Milphio.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What is it? Tell me.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: You are a bad one.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I am a bad one.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: It goes but badly with me.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Just tell me, then; you ought to be in quite other plight. Why is it that it goes badly with you, who have at home in superabundance what to eat, and what to drink? You don't give a single three-obol piece away to a mistress, and have her for nothing.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: May Jupiter so love me----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I' faith, in the degree that you deserve, to wit.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: How I do long for this family to come to ruin.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: If you long for it, lend your aid.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Without feathers it isn't easy to fly: my wings have got no feathers.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Troth, then, don't pluck out any hairs; then, in the next two months, your arm-pits will be fit for flying.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Away to utter perdition!

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Away yourself, and your master!

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: But, really, if a person knew him well, the fellow might soon be ruined.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: * * * Just as though you could be silent on any matter.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I'll keep the matter more strictly secret for you than that which has been told to a dumb woman.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I could easily bring my mind to believe you there, if I did not know you.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Trust me boldly at my own peril.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I shall trust you to my cost, and still I will trust you.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Don't you know that your master is a mortal enemy of my master?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I know it.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: By reason of the love affair?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: You are losing all your pains.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Because you are teaching one that has been taught.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Why, then, do you doubt that my master will do a mischief to your master with pleasure, so far as he can do, with his deserving it? Then besides, if you lend some assistance, on that account he'll be able to do it the more easily.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: But I'm afraid of this, Milphio----

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What is it that you're afraid of?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: That while I'm preparing the plot against my master, I may be betrayed by yourself. If my master knows that I've been talking to any individual, he'll forthwith be making me from Syncerastus into BrokenlegsBrokenlegs: "Crucifragium;" a word coined for the occasion.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: On my word, never shall any mortal be made the wiser by me; only to my master alone will I tell it; and to him, too, in such a way that he shall not disclose that this matter originated in yourself.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I shall trust you at my peril, and yet I will trust you. But do you keep this a secret to yourself.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: To Faith herself it is not more safely confided. Speak out boldly (there's room and opportunity); we are here alone.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: If your master chooses to act with caution, he'll prove the ruin of my master.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Easily.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Then let me be acquainted with this "easily,' that he may know it as well.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Because Adelphasium, whom your master dotes on is free by birth.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: In the same way that her other sister Anterastylis is.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: But how am I to believe that?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: Because he bought them at Anactorium, when little children, of a Sicilian pirate.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: For how much?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: For eighteen minæ.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: with an air of surprise. These two for eighteen minæFor eighteen minœ?: He asks this question, as thirty minæ was about the average price for a single slave.?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: And their nurse for the third. He, too, who sold them told him that he was selling persons who had been kidnapped: he said that they were free-born, and from Carthage.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Ye Gods, by our hopes in you! you mention a most interesting matter; for my master Agorastocles was born in the same place; he was stolen thence when about six years old; after that, the person who stole him brought him here and sold him to my master; that person adopted him as heir to his wealth, when he departed this life.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: You mention everything that can render it the more easy; let him assert their freedom, his own countrywomen, in an action on their freedom.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Only do keep silence and hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: He certainly will bring the Procurer to a backgammon, if he gets them away.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Nay but, I'll cause him to be ruined before he moves one footMoves one foot: "Calcem." By some this word is thought to be used for "calculum," a "chessman," and that reference is made to the use of the word "incitas" in the previous line, which was the mate or backgammon in the game of "duodecim scripta" (somewhat similar to our game of backgammon) and in which " calculi," "pieces" or "chessmen," were used; 'tis so contrived already.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: May the Gods grant it so, that I don't continue the slave of this Procurer.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: On the contrary, upon my faith, I'll cause you to be a free man with myself, if the Gods are willing.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: May the Gods grant it so! Do you detain me for anything else, Milphio?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Fare you well, and may happiness attend you.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I' faith, that lies in the power of yourself and your master. Farewell, and mind that these things have been told in secrecy.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: This has not been mentioned even. Farewell.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: But really it's of no use, unless this is done while it is warm.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: You are right in your advice, and so it shall be done.

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: There's excellent material, if you provide an excellent workman.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Can't you hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: SYNCERASTUS
sp.p: I'll hold my tongue and be off.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: A grand opportunity you've made for me. SYNCERASTUS goes into the house of LYCUS. He's gone from here. The immortal Gods do will my master to be preserved, and this Procurer utterly ruined; a mischief so great is impending upon him. Is it not the fact, before one weapon has been launched, then another presses upon him? I'll go in-doors, that I may recount these matters to my master. For if I were to call him out hither before the house, and, what you've to the AUDIENCE just heard, if I were now here to repeat the same, it would be folly. I'd rather in-doors be an annoyance to my master singly, than be so here to all of you. Immortal Gods, what misfortunes, what great calamities do this day await this Procurer. But now there's no reason why I should delay. This business is resolved upon; no pausing is allowed; for both this must be cleverly managed, which has just now been entrusted to me, and that plan as well which was formed at home must be attended to. If there's any delay, he who sends me a heavy mischance will be acting rightly. Now I'll off in-doors; until my master comes from the Forum, I'll wait at home. Goes into the house of AGORASTOCLES.

div2.stage: Enter HANNO, followed at a distance by his SERVANTS.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: to himself. Hyth alonimHyth alonim: These eighteen lines (or, at least, the first ten) are in Punic, the native language of Hanno. The following is the meaning of them, as given by Plautus in the next eleven lines: "I worship the Gods and Goddesses who preside over this city, that I may have come hither with good omen as to this business of mine, on which I have come; and, ye Gods, lend me your aid, that you may permit me to find my daughters and the son of my cousin; those who were stolen away from me, and his son from my cousin. But here lived formerly my guest Antidamas. They say that he has done that which he was doomed to do. They say that his son Agorastocles lives here. To him am I carrying with me this token of hospitality. He has been pointed as living in this neighbourhood. I'll make enquiry of these who are coming hither out of doors." The learned Bochart, in his Phaleg, considers that the first ten lines are Punic, and that the other eight are, possibly, Lybic, of which the sense had been previously given in Punic; and, in fact, he quite despaired of translating them His translation of the first ten very nearly agrees with that given by Plautus himself. Samuel Petit, in his Miscellanea, considers the whole to be Hebrew, and translates his version (which consists of sixteen lines) as follows: 1. Give ear and attend, O Gods and Goddesses, under whose protection are the men of this city. 2. Receive as acceptable my prayers and my integrity. TwO daughters did I beget, my strength. 3. Urged on by fate, I caused them on each feast-day of the Gods to go to the gardens. 4. With much rejoicing, and on the day of song, there was a void. 5. The girls, being stolen, forsook me. Whither shall I go, pacing all chambers? 6. Where is he who bore them away? that I may remove the helplessness of my sorrow which he produces for me like fruit, in being the father of, and rearing, children. 7. They have said that here, assuredly, Agorastocles lives. 8. I have a token of hospitality, the likeness of Saturn (I'm carrying it), 9. Between us. May there be some end for my journey, that rest at last may be afforded to my integrity. 10. So that alone and wretched and afflicted I may not wander to and fro but rather that I may meet with my children, and pay my vows and oblations 11. To the Gods and Goddesses whom I've invoked as my advisers and assistants, 12. To purify my house from the griefs with which I was affected when I praised them. But they heard not my words, and I am most afflicted and am despondent in mind. 13. O my hope, come hither, and whatever troubles await me, cause me to endure them. Take courage from the truth of oracles, and of the responses of the God Ta=v, from divinations, and forewarnings, and prodigies. 14. Be thou speedily fulfilled; arouse thyself and pray. Would that they could hear: grief would depart from a devout parent, and I should recognize Aristocles, my brother's son. 15. Attentively hear this lamentation, O God, my power, make haste to the truth of thy promise of my exaltation, O God, and my evil odours shall cease. 16. Lo! from henceforth will I to the best of my means show honor, sacrificing spelt to all the Gods, and singing praises!!! vualonuth sicorathi si ma com sith, Chi mach chumyth mumys tyal mictibariim ischi, Lipho canet luth bynuthi ad ædin bynuthii. Birnarob syllo homalonin uby misyrthoho Bythym mothym noctothii velech Antidasmachon. Yssidele berim thyfel yth chylys chon, tern, lyphul Uth bynim ysdibut thinno cuth ru Agorastocles Ythe manet ihy * * chyrsæ lycoch sith naso Byuni id chil luhili gerbylim lasibit thym Bodyalyth herayn nyn nuys lym moncoth lusim. [Exalonim volanus succuratim mistim Atticum esse Concubitum a bello cutim beant lalacant chona Enus es huiec silec panesse Athidamascon Alem * * induberte felono * * buthume Celtum comucro lueni, at enim avoso uber Bent hyach Aristoclem et se te aneche nasoctelia Elicos alemus [in] duberter mi comps vespiti Aodeanee lictor bodes jussum limnicolus.]

div2.stage: Enter AGORASTOCLES, from his house, followed by MILPHIO.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: in a loud voice. Do you say, Milphio, that Syncerastus told you that both of these women were freeborn, and stolen away from Carthage?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I do say so; and if you were willing to act wisely, you'd at once assert their liberty by an action on their freedom. For it's a disgrace to you for you to allow your own country-people to be slaves before your eyes, who were free women at home.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: overhearing, apart. O ye immortal Gods, I do entreat your aid! What speech is this that my ears devour! Surely the words of these persons are made of chalk; how have they cleansed away all the dark spots of woe from me!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: If you've got witnesses of this matter, I'll do as you bid me.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Why speak you to me about witnesses? Why don't you stoutly insist upon it? Some way or other, Fortune will be your assistant.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: It's much more easy to begin a thing than to bring it about.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: catching sight of HANNO, attended by his SERVANTS. But what bird is thisWhat bird is this: The "tunica," or "garment," which Hanno is wearing, has long sleeves, or "manicæ," which causes Milphio to ask if he is a bird, from their resemblance to wings., pray, that's coming hither with the tunic on? Is he from the bathsFrom the baths: He alludes to the practice of thieves making off with the cloaks of persons while bathing at the public baths., I wonder, enveloped in his cloak? I' faith, the countenance is surely Carthaginian. The man's a GuggaA Gugga: Probably a nickname for an African, in ommon use it Rome.. I' faith, he certainly has got some ancient and antiquated servants.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: How do you know?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Don't you see the fellows following, loaded with luggage? And, as I fancy, they've got no fingers on their hands.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Why, because they go with their rings in their earsRings in their ears: The Carthaginians, no doubt, borrowed this custom from the Syrians and Phœnicians, with whom, as also with the Jews, it was prevalent.. I'll approach them, and address them in the Punic language: if they answer, I'll continue to speak in the Punic tongue if not, then I'll adapt my language to their usage. How say you, do you still remember anything of the Punic language?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Nothing at all, i' faith; for tell me, how could I know, who was but six years old when I was stolen away from Carthage?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: apart. O ye immortal Gods! very many freeborn children have been lost from Carthage after this manner.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: How say you?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Should you like me to address this person in the Punic tongue?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Do you understand it?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: No Punic man this day is a better Punic than I.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Go and address him, as to what he wants, why he's come, who he is, of what country, and whence he comes. Don't be sparing of your questions.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: addressing HANNO and his SERVANTS.Avo! Avo: "Hail."Milphio's knowledge of the Punic dialect was probably but limited, though in the sequel it appears that he does know something of it. The translation of these Punic expressions is from Warner's Translation, where the Punic is given in a form somewhat different from that found in the modern editions of the text. Of what country are you, or from what city?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Hanno Muthumballe bachaëdreanech.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What does he say?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He says that he is Hanno from Carthage, a Carthaginian, son of Muthumbal.

sp.speaker: HAN. Avo! MIL.
sp.p: He salutes us.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: DonniDonni: "My masters." Milphio says he is talking about "gifts," from the resemblance of the word to the Latin " doni," the genitive case of "donum " "a gift.".

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He intends to present you with some " donation" out of this; what, I don't know. Don't you hear him promise?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Salute him again in Punic, in my name.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: to HANNO. "Avo donni" he tells me to say to you in his name. Pointing to AGORASTOCLES.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Mehar boccaMehar bocca: This passage has been rendered, "Oh! what a son of tears!" Milphio says he is talking about his "bucca," or "cheek," being in pain. An attempt has been made in the Translation to preserve in some slight degree the resemblance.!

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Be that for yourself rather than me!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What does he say?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He declares that his "box" for his teeth is painful. Perhaps he takes us to be doctors.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: If it is so, tell him that we are not; I don't wish a stranger to be mistaken.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: to HANNO. Hear you. Rufen nuco istamRufen nuco istam: "We are no doctors.".

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: This is my wish, that in fact everything should be explained to him just as it is. Ask him whether he has need of anything.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: to HANNO. You who have got no girdleGot no girdle: The Carthaginian tunic flowed loose, and was not fastened with a girdle. Milphio perhaps alludes to his being without a purse, which was generally supported by the girdle, and without which he might think that a stranger had no business in such a wealthy city as Calydon., why have you come to this city, or what is it you seek?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: MuphursaMuphursa: "Open.".

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What is it he says?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Moin lechiannaMoin lechianna: I beg an entrance for Saturn. Milphio plays upon the very slight resemblance of "muphursa" to "mures," "mice." Under the name of "African mice," he probably alludes to "panthers" or "leopards," which had perhaps been recently shown by the Ædiles, for the first time..

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Why has he come?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Don't you hear? He declares that he is wishful to give African mice to the Ædiles as a show at the games.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Lalech lachananim liminichotLalech lachananim liminichot: "The messenger who asks a safe abode and kind endurance here.".

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What does he say now?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He says he has brought latchets, water- channelsLatchets, water-channels: Milphio plays upon the resemblance of the words "lalech lachananim," to "ligulos canales," which (if the reading is correct) will mean shoestrings and water-pipes--perfect nousense., and nuts; he's now begging that you'll lend him your assistance in having them sold.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: He is a merchant, I suppose?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Is amar binamIs amar binam: "Us unarmed.".

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What is it he says?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Palum erga decthaPalum erga dectha: "Naked men.".

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Milphio, what is he saying now?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He says that he has got spades and forksSpades and forks: Milphio says he is speaking of "palas" and "mergas," "spades" and "pitchforks," by reason of the resemblance in the sound. given him for sale, for digging the garden and reaping the corn.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What is that to me?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He wishes you to be informed of it, so that you mayn't suppose that he has taken anything secretly and by stealth. He has really, I do believe, been sent here to your harvesting.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Muphonium sucoraimMuphonium sucoraim: "'Tis on account of your Deities before invoked..

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: So there! do take care, please, how you do what he's begging of you.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What is he saying, or what is he begging? Explain it.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: For you to order him to be placed beneath a hurdleBeneath a hurdle: Milphio says he is speaking of "crates," "a hurdle." This mode of stoning to death was practised among the Carthaginians., and for many stones to be heaped upon it, so as to put him to death.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Gunebel balsamen ierasan!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Tell me what it is that he's saying.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I' faith, now I really don't at all know.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: speaking in their own language. But that you may know, now from this moment henceforth will I speak Latin. To MILPHIO. Upon my faith, you must be a worthless and bad servant, to be laughing at a person, a foreigner and a stranger.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: But, i' faith, at yourself a person that's both a swindler and a cheat, who have come here to take us in, you half-and-half Lybian, you double-tongue, just like a crawling reptile.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: to MILPHIO. Away hence with your abusiveness! do restrain your tongue. You'll keep it from uttering abuse, if you are prudent; I don't want you to be speaking harshly to my kinsmen. I was born at Carthage; do you remember that.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: O my fellow-countryman, greetings to you!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: And you, troth, whoever you are; and if you have need of anything, pray mention it, and command me for the sake of our common country.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I return you thanks; but I've got a place of entertainment here; I'm in search of the son of Antidamas; do point me out Agorastocles, if you know him. Do you know any young man here named Agorastocles?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: If, indeed, you are in search of the adopted son of Antidamas, I am the very person whom you are in search of.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: starting. Hah! what's that I hear?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: That I am the son of Antidamas.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: If so it is, if you would like to compare the token of hospitalityToken of hospitality: As to the "tessera" of hospitality, see the Cistellaria l. 240, and the Note to the passage., see here, I've brought it. Shows him the ticket.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Come then, show it here. He takes it in his hand, and looks at it. It is exactly true; for I've got the counterpart at home.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: O my host, hail to you right earnestly; for it was your father, then, Antidamas, that was my own and my father's guest; this was my token of hospitality with him.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Then here at my house shall hospitality be shown you; for I don't reject either Hospitality or Carthage, from which I sprang.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: May the Gods grant you all you may desire. How say you? How could it happen that you were born at Carthage, but had a father of Ætolia here?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I was stolen away from there; this Antidamas, your guest, bought me, and adopted me as his son.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: He himself, likewise, was adopted by Demarchus, But about him I say no more, and return to you. Tell me, de you at all remember the names of your parents?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I remember my father and my mother's name.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Repeat them, then, to me, to see if I know them, perchance, or if they are relatives of mine.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Ampsigura was my mother, and Iachon my father.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I could wish that your father and mother were alive.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Are they dead?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: So it is, a thing which I bore with much grief; for your mother Ampsigura was my cousin-german; your father--he was my uncle's son, and when he died he made me his heir; of whom being deprived by death, I am greatly affected. But if it is the fact that you really are the son of Sachon, there ought to be a mark upon your left hand, a bite which an ape gave you when a child, playing with it. Show it, that I may look at it; open your hand.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: opening his hand. Look, if you like; see, there it is. My kinsman, welcome to you!

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: And welcome to you, Agorastocles! I seem to myself to be born again, in having found you.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: By my troth, I'm delighted that this matter has fallen out so happily foryou. To HANNO. And would you decline to take advice?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Really, I should wish to be advised.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: His father's property ought to be restored to the son; it's fair that he should have the property which his father possessed.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I wish no otherwise; everything shall be restored. I'll give his own property to him all safe, when he comes there.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Take care and restore it, will you, even though he should live here still.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Nay but, he shall have my own as well, if anything should happen to meAnything should happen to me: An Euphemism to avert all omen..

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: A pleasant project has just now come into my mind,

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: There's need of your assistance.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Tell me what you wish. Really, you shall have my services just as you please. What is the business?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Can you act the cheat?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Towards an enemy, I can; to a friend, it would be mere folly.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I' faith, it is an enemy of his. Pointing at AGORASTOCLES.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I could do him a mischief with pleasure.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He's in love with a person who belongs to a Procurer.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I deem that he acts discreetly.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: This Procurer lives close at hand.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I could do him a mischief with pleasure.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He has two slave girls, courtesans, sisters; one of these he is desperately in love with, nor has he ever taker any liberties with her.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: It's an unhappy kind of passion.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: The Procurer plays upon him.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: He's enhancing his own profits thereby.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He wishes to do him an evil turn.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: He's right, if he does do it.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Now I adopt this plan, and prepare this contrivance, that we should. cite you; you are to affirm that they are your daughters, and that they were stolen when little from Carthage, and to maintain the cause of both in an action on their freedom, as though they were both your own daughters. Do you understand?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: On my faith, I do understand; for I likewise did have two daughters who were stolen away when little children, together with their nurse.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Upon my word, you do feign it cleverly. At the very commencement this amuses me.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: aside, weeping. Much more, i' troth, than I could wish.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: aside to AGORASTOCLES. Dear me! a subtle person, upon my word, artful and knowing, both tricky and crafty! How he does whimper, in order that with his gestures he may effect this all the more easily. Even myself, now, the master-workman, does he excel in skill.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: But their nurseBut their nurse: It did not escape the accurate Schmieder that the fact has not been hitherto communicated to Hanno that the damsels had a nurse who was stolen. This, then, is either an oversight of Plautus, or he must mean that Hanno thinks he has asked the question, and has received an answer in the affirmative., of what appearance was she? Tell me.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Of stature not tall, of a dusky complexionOf a dusky complexion: "Aquilo." "Of he hue of deep water.".

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: 'Tis the very person.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Of agreable form, with a small mouth, and very dark eyes.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I' faith, you really have depicted her form exactly in your words.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Should you like to see her?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I'd rather see my daughters. Still, go and call her out of doors. If they are my daughters, if she is their nurse, she'll recognize me at once.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: knocking at the door of the PROCURER'S house. Hallo there! is there any one here? Tell Giddeneme to come out of doors; there's a person wants to see her.

div2.stage: Enter GIDDENEME and a BOY, from the house.

sp.speaker: GIDDENEME
sp.p: Who is it that knocks?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: One that's a near acquaintance of yours.

sp.speaker: GIDDENEME
sp.p: What do you want?

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Come now pointing to HANNO, do you know that person in the tunic, who it is?

sp.speaker: GIDDENEME
sp.p: Why, whom do I behold? O supreme Jupiter! this sure is my master, the father of my foster-children, Hanno, the Carthaginian!

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Now, do see the cunning hussey this Carthaginian is really a clever juggler; he has brought all over to his own opinion.

sp.speaker: GIDDENEME
sp.p: running up to HANNO. O my master! welcome to you, Hanno! most unhoped for by myself and your daughters, welcome to you! But look you, don't be wondering, or gazing so intently upon me. Don't you know Giddeneme, your female slave?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I know her. But where are my daughters? That I'm longing to know.

sp.speaker: GIDDENEME
sp.p: At the Temple of VenusTemple of Venus: Venus was the tutelar Divinity of Calydon..

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: What are they doing there? Tell me.

sp.speaker: GIDDENEME
sp.p: To-day is the Aphrodisia, the festive day of Venus! they have gone there to entreat the Goddess to be propitious to them.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: I' faith, they've fully prevailed, I'm sure, inasmuch as he has arrived here.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: aside to GIDDENEME. How now, are these his daughters?

sp.speaker: GIDDENEME
sp.p: Just as you say. To HANNO. Your kindness has clearly come to our rescue, in your having arrived here to-day at the very time; for this day their names were to have been clangedNames were to have been changed: The "professæ," or "courtesans," at. Rome, were registered by the Ædiles, and usually adopted some other than their family name for the purposes of their calling., and they were to have made a livelihood, disgraceful to their station, by their persons.

sp.speaker: A BOY.
sp.p: Haudones illiHaudones illi: Shall I not bid him welcome?.

sp.speaker: GIDDENEME
sp.p: Havon bene si illi, in mustine. Me ipsi et eneste dum et alamna cestinumAlamna cestinum: "Child, remember that they are at the Festival of Venus. The time is not proper as yet. Hold your peace at present, and keep the Captain in ignorance of this.".

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What is it they are saying among themselves? Tell me.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: He's saluting his mother, and she this her son.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Hold your peace, and let alone the woman's gear.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: What gear is that?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Loud talking without limit. To MILPHIO. Do you lead these people in-doors pointing to his SERVANTS, and bid this nurse to come away together with you to your house.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: to MILPHIO. Do as he requests.

sp.speaker: GIDDENEME
sp.p: to HANNO. But who's to point them out to you?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I will, right skilfully.

sp.speaker: GIDDENEME
sp.p: I'll go away then.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I'd only rather that you would do so, than say so. She goes into the house of AGORASTOCLES.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: Upon my faith, I do think that this day the very thing that I said by way of joke will be coming to pass both soberly and seriously, that these will be discovered to-day to be his daughters.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Troth, that very thing is quite certain now. Do you, Milphio, take them pointing to the SERVANTS in-doors; we'll wait here for these damsels. I wish a dinner to be got ready for my kinsman on his arrival.

sp.speaker: MILPHIO
sp.p: LachananimLachananim: "Get on with you. and be thankful," according to Petit. you! aside to the SERVANTS, whom I'll just now be packing off to the mill-stones, and from there after that to the dungeon and the oaken logThe oaken log: The "codex" was a heavy log to which slaves were chained, and which they were condemned to drag about with them. It is hard to say why Milphio speaks thus harshly to the servants of Hanno; perhaps however all this is said in a jocular way to show his own importance.. I'll give you reason to praise your treatment here but slightly.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: to HANNO. Do you hear, kinsman? I say, don't you revoke what has been said; promise me your elder daughter in marriage.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Consider the thing as agreed on.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Do you promise her, then?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I do promise her.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: My kinsman, blessings on you! for now you are mine beyond a doubt; now at length shall I converse with her without restraint. Now, kinsman, if you wish to see your daughters, follow me.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Why, really, this long time I've been longing for it, and I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What if we go and meet them?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: But I'm afraid lest we should pass them on the road. Great Jupiter, do now reinstate my fortunes for me as being certain instead of uncertain!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I trust that my charmer will be my own. But look, I catch sight of them.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: What, are these my daughters? How tall from being such little creatures have they now become!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Do you know how it is? These are Grecian columnsGrecian columns: He seems to allude to their upright way of walking, and the elegance of the Grecian columns, to which he compares them.; they are wont to be erect. They stand aside.

div2.stage: Enter ADELPHASIUM and ANTERBASTYLIS, from the Temple of Venus.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: 'Twas worth the while, to-day, of him who has a taste for loveliness to afford a feast to his eyes, in coming hither to the Temple this day to see the sights. Upon my faith, I was charmed there to-day with the most elegant offerings of the courtesans, worthy of Venus, the most handsome Goddess; nor did I despise her worship this day; so great an abundance of beauteous objects was there there, each nicely arranged in its own place. The odours of Arabia and of myrrh filled everything. The festive day seemed to be affected with no gloom, Venus, nor did thy Temple; so great a throng of her dependants was there, who had come to Venus of Calydon.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: But certainly, as far indeed as regarded us two, sister, we were all-powerful in our prayers, beauteous and gainers of her favour; neither were we there held in ridicule by the young men, which, i' faith, sister, happened to all the rest.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: I'd rather that it should so appear to other persons, than that you, sister, should praise yourself.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: Indeed, I trust so.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Troth, and so do I, when I reflect of what breeding we and the others are. We were born in that station, that it befits us to be unblemished by faultiness.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: apart. Jupiter, who dost preserve and feed the race of men, through whom we pass this mortal life, in whose hands are the hopes of life in all men, prithee, do grant this day as a prosperous one for my fortunes! Those whom I've missed for many years, and whom when little I lost from their native land, to them restore their liberty, that I may be sure that for an indomitable sense of duty there is a reward.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: apart. I'll engage that Jove shall do it all; for to me he is indebtedTo me he is indebted: This impious expression is out of character with Agorastocles, and the latter portion of the line is supposed to be spurious., and stands in awe of me.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: apart. Prithee, do hold your peace. He weeps.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: apart. Kinsman, do not weep.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: apart. As it is a pleasure for a man, my sister, if he succeeds in anything, to have the credit of victory, just so did we this day among the rest excel them all in beauty.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Sister, you are more silly than I could wish. Prithee, do you really think yourself a beauty, if your face has not been besmeared with sootBesmeared with soot: Douza informs us that it was the custom of the young men to divert themselves at the expense of those courtesans who were not handsome, by daubing their faces with soot and dirt.?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: apart. O kinsman! O kinsman, dearest of all kinsmenDearest of all kinsmen: 'Patruissime." A word coined by Plautus for the occasion. to me!

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: apart. What is it, son of my cousin? My son, tell me, what is it you wish?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: apart. Why, really, I do wish you to attend to this.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: apart. Why, really, I am attending to it.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: apart. Kinsman, kinsman, dearest of all kinsmen to me!

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: apart. What's the matter? AGO. apart. She's a clever and a nice girl. How shrewd she is!

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: apart. She has her father's disposition in being shrewd.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: apart. How's that? This long time, i' faith, she has surely used up your shrewdness. 'Tis from here pointing to himself she now derives her shrewdness; 'tis from here her sense; whatever she does shrewdly, through my love does she act so shrewdly.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: We are not born of that rank, although we are slaves, sister, that it should befit us to do anything which any man may laugh at. Many are the faults of women; but of the many, this one is the greatest, to please themselves too much, and to give their attention too little to pleasing the men.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: It was a very great delight that was portended in our sacrifice of the entrails, sister, and what the soothsayer said about us both----

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: apart. I wish he had said something about me!

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: That we should be free in a few days, in spite of our owner. I don't know why I should hope for that, unless the Gods or our parents do something.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: apart. 'Twas through confidence in meThrough confidence in me: He surmises that the soothsayer (like most other successful prophets) had learnt the true state of the case beforehand., kinsman, upon my faith, that the soothsayer promised them liberty, I'm sure of it, because he knows I'm in love with her.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Sister, follow me this way. Moves as if going.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: I follow. Moves also.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: stepping forward. Before you go awayBefore you go away: Warner, in his Note on this passage, suggests that Plautus has here forgotten the rules of nature. He says, "It is unnatural to suppose a parent, who has so long been in search of his daughters, should be so near them as to see them, and hear them talk, and not immediately fly into their embraces. And when he does speak to them, he teases and torments them a long time, for no other reason than to divert the Spectators.", I want you both. Unless it's inconvenient, stop.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Who's calling us back?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: One who wishes to do you a kindness.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: There's opportunity for doing it. But who is the person?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: A friend of yours.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: One> who is not an enemy, in fact.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: This is a good man, my love.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: I' faith, I should prefer him rather than a bad one.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: If, indeed, friendship must be engaged in, with such a person ought it to be engaged in.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: I don't beg for it.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: He wishes to do you many services.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Being good yourself you will be doing good to the good.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I will cause you joy----

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: And, i' faith, we pleasure to you.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: And liberty.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: At that price you'll easily make us your own.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: My kinsman, so may the Gods bless me, if I were Jupiter, upon my faith I'd at once marry her for my wife, and pack Juno out of doors. How quietly did she utter her words, how considerately and becomingly! how modestly did she frame her speech! certainly she is my own!

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: apart to AGORASTOCLES. But how skilfully I accosted her!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Cleverly and becomingly, upon my faith.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Am I still to go on testing them?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Compress it in a few words; the people who are sitting here are getting thirstySitting here are getting thirsty: He alludes to the Spectators, and means that they must be tired with sitting there and listening to such a long Play..

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Well, why don't we proceed to do that which was to be done? To the WOMEN. I summon you to justice.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Seize hold of this one, kinsman, if you are wise. Should you like me to catch hold of her?

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Is this person your kinsman, Agorastocles?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I'll soon let you know. Now, by my word, I'll be nicely revenged on you; for I'll make----you my bride.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Come before a court of justice; don't delay!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Summon me as your witnessSummon me as your witness: 'Antestare me." See the Note to the Curculio, l. 621., and take me; I'll be a witness for you; and after that, her pointing to ADELPHASIUM will I love and embrace. But 'twas this, indeed, I intended to say--why yes, I did say that which I intended to say.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: to the DAMSELS. You are lingering. I summon you to justice, unless it is more becoming for you to be dragged thither.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Why do you summon us to justice? What are we in your debt?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: He'll tell it there.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Are even my own dogs barking at me?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Then, troth, do you caress me; give me a kiss in place of a piece of meat; present your lips in place of a boneYour lips in place of a bone: The original of this line is somewhat indelicate, and the translation of it has been modified. She expected assistance from Agorastocles, who appears to her to be taking the part of her enemy.: that way I'll render this dog more smooth for you than oil.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Come on, if you are coming.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: What have we done to you?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: You are thieves, both of you.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: What, we, as regards you?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: You, I say.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: And I know it.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: What theft is this?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Enquire of him.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Because for many years you have been concealing my daughters from me, and, in fact, persons free-born, and free, and born of the highest rank.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: I' faith, you'll never find that villany to have been committed by us.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Make a bet of a kiss now, if you are not forsworn, which is to give it to the other.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: I've nothing to do with you; prithee, get you gone.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: But, i' faith, I've got something to do with you; for he is my kinsman; it's necessary for me to be his advocate. And I'll inform him how you are guilty of many a theft, and in what way you have got his daughters as slaves at your house, whom you know to be free women stolen from their native land.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Where are these, or who are they, prithee?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: aside to HANNO. They have been teased sufficiently.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: aside. Why not speak out, then?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: aside. I' faith, I'm of that opinion, kinsman.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: I'm dreadfully afraid what this business can mean, my sister; so astounded am I, I stand here without my senses.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Damsels, give me your attention. In the first place, if it could possibly come to pass, for the Gods not to send upon the innocent what is undeserved, that could I have wished to happen; now for the good the Gods bestow upon me, upon yourselves and upon your nurseAnd upon your nurse: "Matri." This may either mean their own mother, the wife of Hanno, if then living, or their nurse Giddeneme: as "mater" is used in the latter sense by Plautus in the Prologue to the Menæchmi., 'tis due that we should give to the Deities our endless thanks, since the immortal Gods approve and reward our piety. You are my daughters, both of you, and this is your relation, Agorastocles, the son of my cousin.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Prithee, are they deluding us with imaginary joys?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Really, so may the Deities preserve me, this is your father. Give him your hands.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: embracing him. Welcome, father! unhoped-for by us, allow us to embrace you!

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: embracing him. Welcome, father! much wished and longed for! We are both your daughters; we both embrace you.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Who'll be for embracing me in the next place?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Now am I happy! Now with this delight do I allay the miseries of many a year.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: We hardly seem to believe this.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I'll tell you something to make you believe it the more: why, it was your nurse who recognized me first.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: Prithee, where is she?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: pointing to AGORASTOCLES. She's at his house.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: to ADELPHASIUM, who is embracing her father. Pray, why does it please you to clasp his neck so long, before he has betrothed you to me? Dear one, much longed-for, blessings on you! He embraces her.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: struggling. Do leave off your salutations!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: I will leave off. And you the other one. To ANTERASTYLIS, whom he embraces.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: struggling. I don't want that; you torment me to death!

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Let us each clasp the other in our arms, than whom is there anything on earth more happy?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Blessings befall the deserving. Pointing to HANNO. At last his wishes are realized! O Apelles! O ZeuxisApelles! O Zeuxis: Apelles of Cos flourished in the time of Alexander the Great. He was the most celebrated painter of his time. Zeuxis of Heraclæa flourished about a century before him, and was equally famous as a painter the painter! why did you die too soon? Would that you could paint a subject after this! For I don't care for other common painters to be treating subjects of this description.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Gods and Goddesses all! I return you deservedly extreme thanks, for having blest me with this gladness so supreme and with these joys so great; as my daughters have returned to me and into my possession.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: My father, your own piety has clearly come to our aid.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Kinsman, take care and keep it in memory that you've betrothed your elder daughter to me----

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I remember it.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: The portion, too, that you promised.

div2.stage: Enter ANTHEMONIDES, from the house of LYCUS.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: to himself. If I don't take full revenge for that mina which I gave to the Procurer, then really may the townspeople make a butt of me! This most rascally fellow even brought me to his house to breakfast. He himself went away out of doors, and left me as his chamberlainAs his chamberlain: "Atriensi." The duties of this domestic are fully referred to in the Notes to the Asinaria. in the house. When neither the Procurer nor these women came back, nor anything was given me to eat, for the best part of the breakfast I took a pledgeI took a pledge: It is not quite clear what he refers to, but he probably means to say that he has laid hold of something valuable in the Procurer's house, which will, at all events, procure a substitute in part for the prandium" out of which he has been cheated, and came out of doors. This way I'll pay him. I'll touch up the rascally Procurer in the military way of paymentMilitary way of payment: By the mention of "æs militare," some Commentators think that he alludes to his sword, and draws it. He seems to refer, however, to the stipend which the soldiers receive for their services, with full liberty to lay their hands on anything that belongs to the enemy.. He did get hold of a person for him to bamboozle out of a mina of silver! But I wish that my mistress would now come in my way while thus enraged. Then, by my troth, with my fists I'd make her quite black all over; I'd cover her so with swarthiness, that she should be much more swarthy than the Egyptians, or than those who carry the bucketsCarry the buckets: He alludes to the slaves whose duty it was to hold the buckets to the horses in the Circus for them to drink from. Exposure to sun and dust would tend to render them swarthy. at the games in the Circus.

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: running to AGORASTOCLES. Do hold me fast, please, my love; I sadly fear the kites; this is an evil animal--lest perchance he may carry me off, your chick.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: embracing her FATHER. I cannot clasp you fast enough, my father!

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: to himself. I'm delaying. Looking in his hand. I can now pretty nearly cater a breakfast for myself with this. Raising his eyes. But what's this? How's this? What's this? What's this I see? How now? What means this strange conjunction? What's this coupling together? Who's this fellow with the long skirts, just like a tavern-boy? Do I quite see with my eyes? Isn't this my mistress, Anterastylis? Why, surely it is she. For some time past I've perceived that I'm set at nought. Isn't the girl ashamed to be hugging a tawny fellow in the middle of the street? I faith, I shall give him up forthwith to the executioner to be tortured all over. Surely this is a womanish raceA womanish race: "Muliersous" generally means "fond of women." It clearly however, in this passage means "womanish," or "womanlike.", with their tunics hanging down to their heels. But I'm determined to accost this African female lover. To HANNO. Hallo! you woman, I say, are you not ashamed? What business have you with her, pray? Tell me.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Young man, greetings to you.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: I don't want them; that's nothing to you. What business have you to touch her with a finger?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Because I choose.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: You choose?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I say so.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Away to utter perdition, you shoe-latchet! What, do you dare to be acting the lover here, you great toe of a manYou great toe of a man: From this expression it has been conjectured that Hanno was a man of diminutive stature, and that the Play took its name of Pœnulus, "the little Carthaginian," from that circumstance., or to be meddling with an object which masculine men are fond of, you skinnea pilchard, you deformed image of SerapisOf Serapis: It is not fully known what the meaning of "Sarapis" is, as it occurs nowhere else. It has been conjectured, that, owing to the African features of Hanno, the Captain compares him to the little ugly images of Serapis, which were carried about in harvest-time by the priests of that God, for the purpose of collecting money., you half-apron, you sheepskin-jacketYou sheepskin-jacket: This garment, being worn with the wool on, was remarkable for its offensive smell. "Halagoras hama" is supposed to mean the pots of common sea-salt exposed for sale in the market-place., you pot of stinking sea-salt; more crammed, too, to boot, with leeks and garlick than the Roman rowers?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Young man, do your jaws or your teeth itch, that you are annoying this person, or are you in search of a heavy mishap?

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Why didn't you use a drumUse a drum: The priests of Cybele, who were either eunuchs, or persons of effeminate and worthless character, walked in their processions beating a "tympanum." a "drum" or "tambourine." The Captain, by his question, contemptuously implies that Agorastocles is such a character. See the Truer lentus, l. 608, and the Note. while you were saying that? For I take you to be more of an effeminate wretch than a real man.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Do you understand what sort of effeminate wretch I am? Calling aloud. Servants, come out of doors, bring out some cudgels!

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Hark you, if I have said anything in a joke, don't you be for taking it seriously.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: Prithee, what pleasure have you, Anthemonides, in speaking rudely to our kinsman and father? For this is our father; he has just now recognized us, and him as the son of his cousin.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: So may Jupiter kindly bless me, I heartily rejoice that it is so, and I am delighted, if, in fact, any great misfortune befalls this Procurer, and since a fortune awaits you equal to your merits.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: I' faith, he says what's worthy of belief; do believe him, my father.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I do believe him.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: And I believe him. But look pointing, I espy the Procurer Lycus, the worthy fellow; look, there he is--he's betaking himself homeward.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Who is this?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: He's which you please, both the Procurer and Lycus. He has been keeping your daughters in servitude, and from myself he has stolen some gold.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: A pretty fellow for you to be acquainted with!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Let's bring him to justice.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Because 'twere better for an action of damages to be brought against himAction of damages to be brought against him: "Multum dici" has been adopted as the reading, in preference to "multo induci," which seems capable of no translation consistently with sense. The passage may possbly mean that he prefers an action at law to summary proceedings..

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: to himself. No one, in my opinion at least, is deceived, who rightly states his case to his friends. But by all my friends the one same thing is agreed upon, that I ought to hang myself, so as not to be adjudged to Agorastocles.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: stepping forward. Procurer, let's away to the court of justice.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I do entreat you, Agorastocles, that I may be at liberty to hang myself.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I summon you to justice.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: But what have you to do with me?

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: pointing at his DAUGHTERS. Because I affirm that both of these are my daughters, free women, and free by birth, who, when little, were kidnapped together with their nurse.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Indeed, I knew that already, and I wondered that no one came to assert their freedom; they really are none of mine, indeed.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Procurer, you must come to justice.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: You are talking about the breakfast; it is owing to you; I'll give it.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Twofold compensation I must have for the theft.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: pointing to his neck. Take it out of this, then.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: And I require a full satisfaction.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: pointing to his neck. Take out of this whatever you please. ANTH. And I, indeed, a mina of silver.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: pointing to his neck. Take out of this whatever you please. I'll at once settle the matter for all with my neck, just like a porter.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Do you refuse me in any way?

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Not a word, in fact.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Go in-doors, then, damsels. But to HANNO, my kinsman, betroth me your daughter, as you promised.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I should not venture to do otherwise.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Kindly farewell!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: And kindly farewell to you!

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: holding up what he has got in his hand. Procurer, I take this as a pledge with me for my mina.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: By heavens, I am ruined!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Why yes, before very long, when you've come to justice.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Nay but, I own myself your slave. What need of the Prætor have we? But I beseech you that I may be allowed to pay the simple sumPay the simple sum: In lieu of paying double the amount, as he might be forced at law to do, for being an accomplice in the theft., three hundred Philippeans. I think it can be scraped together; to-morrow I'll have an auction.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: On condition, then, that you shall be in wooden custody at my house.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: So be it.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Follow me in-doors, my kinsman, that we may keep this festive day in joyousness, upon his misfortune and our good fortune. To the AUDIENCE. Heartily fare you well. To great length have we gone; at last all these misfortunes fall upon the Procurer. Now--that which is the last seasoning for our Play--if it has pleased you, our Comedy asks applause.

div2.stage: AGORASTOCLES, LYCUS, HANNO, ANTHEMONIDES, ADELPHASIUM, and ANTERASTYLIS.Many of the ancient MSS. contain this additional Scene, which is generally supposed not to have been the composition of Plautus. It is not improbable that at some period the last Scene may have been lost, and that the present one may have been composed to supply its place, as it is evidently not the composition of a person who was aware of the existence of the Scene which precedes it.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: What is it you are about, Captain? Why does it please you to speak rudely to my relative? Don't be surprised that the damsels do follow after him; he has just now discovered that both of them are his own daughters.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: starting. Hah! what speech was it that reached my ears? Now I am undone! To AGORASTOCLES. From what house were these females lost?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: They are Carthaginians.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Then I am ruined. I was always in dread of that, lest some one should recognize them, a thing which has now come to pass. Woe unto wretched me! My eighteen minæ are lost, I guess, which I paid for them.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: And you yourself are lost, Lycus.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Who is this?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Which you please, he's either the Procurer or Lycus. He has been keeping your daughters in servitude, and from myself he has stolen some gold.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: A pretty fellow for you to be acquainted with!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Procurer, I always deemed you to be avaricious, but they know you to be a thief as well, who know more of you.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I'll approach him. He falls on the ground before AGORASTOCLES. By your knees I do beseech you, and by him pointing to HANNO, whom I understand to be your relative; since you are deserving persons, as it befits deserving persons to do, do then come to the aid of your suppliant! Indeed, already did I know them to be free women, and was waiting for some one to claim their freedom, for really they are none of mine. Then besides, I'll restore your gold that I've got in my house, and I'll make oath that I have done nothing, Agorastocles, with ill intent.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: As it's right for me to do, I shall still consult my own notions. Let go of my knees.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I'll let them go, if such is your determination. He rises from the ground, and retires to a distance.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Hark you! Procurer.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: What do you want with a Procurer amid business?

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: You to restore me my money before I take you hence to be laid in fetters.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: May the Gods grant better things!

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Even so; you'll be dining away from home. I see Gold, silver, and your neck, Procurer, the three things are you now owing to me all at once.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: What it befits me to do in this matter, I'm considering with myself. If I should attempt to take vengeance on this fellow, I shall be engaging in litigation in a strange city. So far as I hear, his disposition and manners, of the nature that they are----

sp.speaker: ADELPHASIUM
sp.p: My father, do have no dealings with this man, I conjure you.

sp.speaker: ANTERASTYLIS
sp.p: Do listen to my sister. Come, put an end to your strife with the rascal.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: Attend to this, will you, Procurer. Although I know that you deserve to come to ruin, I'll not try the matter with you.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Nor I, if you restore me my gold; Procurer, when let go from the fetters--you may get thrust into prison.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: What, your old habit still?

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Carthaginian, I wish to excuse myself to you. If I have said anything in my passion against the inclination of your feelings, I beg that you will pardon it; and as you have found these daughters of yours, so may the Deities bless me, it is a pleasure to me.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I both forgive and believe you.

sp.speaker: ANTERLASTYIS
sp.p: Procurer, do you take care either to find me a mistress, or return me the mina of gold.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: Should you like to have my music-girl?

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: I don't care for a music-girl; you don't know which is the greater, their cheeks or their bosoms.

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: I'll find one to please you.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Mind that,

sp.speaker: LYCUS
sp.p: to AGORASTOCLES. To-morrow I'll bring back your gold to your house.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Take care that you keep that in memory. Captain, follow me.

sp.speaker: ANTHEMONIDES
sp.p: Yes, I'll follow you. LYCUS goes into his house.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: to HANNO. How say you, kinsman? When are you thinking of leaving here for Carthage?--for I'm determined to go together with you.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: As soon as ever I can, that instant I shall go.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: It's necessary for you to stop here some days, until I've had an auction.

sp.speaker: HANNO
sp.p: I'll do just as you wish.

sp.speaker: AGORASTOCLES
sp.p: Come, please, let's be off; let's enjoy ourselves To the AUDIENCE. Grant us your applause.]
